field_edited_text.value:
o

Goal:

Realize the full potential of the
harbor’s shoreline and water
area for recreational uses and
public access.



2

Inner Harbor, public plaza and shoreline promenade

With the industrialization of the har-
bors shoreline during the late 19th and
early 20th centuries most of the public
recreational facilities were displaced by fac-
tories, bulk storage or marine terminals.
Riverview Rark in Canton disappeared in
the late 1920’s as Western Electric devel-
oped its plant; Canton Race Track is now
Exxon’s storage yards; Fletchers Fish House
and Beer Garden constructed in 1809, dis-
appeared under railyards and highways in
the Middle Branch in the 1850’s. In virtually
every area of the harbor large, public recre-
ational facilities have been replaced by
industrial development. As industrial and
port uses grew, communities were isolated
from the waterfront and public access to
the shoreline became virtually non-existent.
By the mid 1940’s, Baltimore’s citizens who
had once looked to the Bay, and the water
for a major recreational pastime had few
opportunities to use this resource. Less
than one mile of the Port’s 28 mile long
shoreline was available to public access.
With so few opportunities for public access
the City must work carefully to see that
each public park and shoreline access
opportunity:is developed and maintained
to serve the greatest number of people
possible.



103
